What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to design, prototype, and make a medical device as well as the processes regarding approval and patenting
I learned so many new skills applicable to any internships or industry related positions.

We learned how to model in SolidWorks and run finite element analysis, and about the medical device market/industry. Experts in each field came to speak to us about their experiences and advice. They also introduced us to the entire entrepreneurial process from designing to FDA approval. From the group projects, we were able to work with a New Haven physician to apply what we learned in the class and design our own medical device.

- Process of designing a novel medical device (from problem to design to prototype to commercialization)
- Learned from different professionals in all areas of the biomedical/healthcare/medical devices industries thanks to all the guest lectures

I learned the basics of biomedical engineering, learned about the process of product design and the basics of intellectual property, and learned about how to use programs including SolidWorks, ScanIP, and Abaqus. I learned how to conduct a failure analysis and how to work with a team to design a medical device.

I learned more about the biotechnology industry and and start-up process. I began work with Solidworks, and learned how to use ScanIP and Abaqus, as well as learning how to 3D print models. These are all something that I have valued especially for real-world experience.
Innovation process, regulatory process, hospital workflow, medical device patents, femoral fractures and implants, Scan IP software basics, SolidWorks software basics

I learned about the engineering design process, patent law, and what various career paths are like post-grad. When shadowing surgeries, I was able to much better understand the process and gained medical knowledge in addition to engineering skills.
furthered by clinical knowledge and also my knowledge of the medical device design process

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great class in that it covered a lot of interesting areas that were not mentioned in traditional classes, but the timeframe for the projects made it hard to get a lot of progress/results

Strengths: Passionate, accessible, and knowledgable professors and TFs, very interesting material covered in lectures, hands-on projects, wonderful mentors
Weaknesses: Crunched time to work on final projects due to the other (slightly frustrating) class assignment for modeling and FEA

Strengths: guest lectures, semester long design project, weekly office hours
I loved having the design project for the whole semester -- it really gave us a chance to start from the problem and go through the actual process of designing and reiterating the design and then finally prototyping. Pairing groups up with a mentor (the person who posed the problem) was incredibly helpful and I loved being able to get that weekly engagement with Dr. Caty (our mentor). It definitely was more difficult being in the virtual environment but I am glad we were able to work together well.

Weaknesses: The failure analysis project at the beginning of the semester was definitely incredibly interesting, especially learning how to create an actual 3D image out of a bone scan and then meshing a plate onto the model. However, I believe the whole process going from creating the model to actually performing failure analysis was a huge leap and I wish we had more time to work through it. I know many groups ran into problems doing the actual failure analysis, likely because our models had a lot of parts and we probably didn't do some of the little things that could have made the program run faster/smoother. However, we didn't have enough time in the class to truly explore all the tools in ScanIP and Abaqus to make our models run successfully. Furthermore, the project took away from time dedicated to the actual design project as it was a bit frustrating not getting the model to work. Thus, with this being said, I do believe it would be helpful to either cut down the failure analysis project (ie. already having a model for everyone and then having us do the failure analysis in Abaqus OR doing the ScanIP model building + a simpler failure analysis in Abaqus with less moving parts and thus less possibility of model failure). Otherwise, spending a bit more time on the failure analysis would likely help as well!

This course was amazing! The professors are wonderful and very open to helping students learn and develop their devices. My only wish is that the course could have been completely in person, which of course was not possible due to COVID.

There were a lot of assignments for this class that felt really superfluous. At the start of the semester, we were told to complete half a dozen long trainings for spaces and machines, most of which we did not need. The two primary projects, the midterm failure analysis project and final device design project could have been better laid out. Few groups could start their final project until after they started their failure analysis project, and the failure analysis project was poorly organized, with unclear descriptions and expectations. You could only complete the failure analysis project if you left things to the last minute, as it was highly likely that one of the professors would change the requirements 24 hours before it was due, or suddenly remember a crucial step that they had previously forgot to tell the students to complete. Fortunately, Professor Tommasini and Dr. Wiznia were both extraordinarily kind, kind, and willing to help, which combined with the good TA's made this class way better. The final project would have been more engaging if we had more time to work on it, instead of splitting our time between the failure analysis project. This class was a good introduction to the process of medical device design, but in its current iteration don't have high expectations for actually designing a medical device.

Strengths - a lot of very great speakers came to talk and it helps prepare students for the industry rather than just more schooling. It is one of the few classes for BME majors to get hands-on experience using the CEID and other programs like Solidworks.
Weaknesses - the class is a little disorganized, there was no set point on how far people needed to get with their projects.

Strengths: Really cool to have a team-based project where we actually create something tangible by the end of the semester; great professor and TA availability for help with software and projects; interesting and engaging lectures; really engaging and eye-opening field trips were the highlight of the class

Weaknesses: The course felt somewhat disorganized and disjointed with all of the guest lectures; at times, when we were given guidance with the Scan IP and failure analysis software, it felt more like we were given steps to follow and memorized rather than being taught the underlying principles to understand and apply to projects going forward-- at times, office hours felt like the time that the instructors used to figure out the appropriate steps to take when using the software themselves, so following along could be confusing; we also received no grades and little to no feedback on our work throughout the semester

This course was incredible. Even with all the restrictions imposed by COVID, we still were given cool opportunities, both in person and virtually. The workload was not extremely high, but all of the teams still produced some pretty cool things by the end of the term.
some of the lectures about brainstorming could have been given earlier in the course

The strengths are the professors, guest speakers, and projects.

The weaknesses are the format of the course and the semester schedule. The failure analysis project was a disaster. It required a lot of debugging and working through very laggy software with license issues. I don't feel like I learned anything about failure analysis. I just learned how to complete a specific assignment and kinda of get the software functioning. The problems with this project were made much worse by being mostly online. Unless this project is re-configured I do not think it should be included in future years. It was incredibly frustrating. 

The end of year projects are great but the time allocated is way too small. If I were designing the course, I would greatly simplify and shorten the failure analysis project in order to get to the term projects as fast as possible.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: n/a

I would say nothing much changed other than the fact everything was done online for the most part, with the exception of some live lectures at the beginning of the year. I would say it was relatively successful in communication between teams and the lectures for class as well.
The virtual lectures were engaging and office hours with breakout rooms were helpful.

I was really grateful to be able to have some safe, in-person components to this class, including two really engaging field trips and a few socially distanced lectures. Otherwise, most of the lectures and all office hours were online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great class if you are really interested in working on medical devices in the future
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone else!
Yes! But similar to any other project-based class, be sure to get on a good team. Nothing is worse than doing a whole project alone.

Yes! If you want the experience of going from problem to solution (with all the steps in between from brainstorming to designing to prototyping), this is the class for you! Furthermore, you'll be able to hear from experts in their various fields as well as some industry speakers who will all offer some valuable advice and insight on not only new innovations in the market, but also present you with options for different careers post-graduation!
Absolutely. It was an excellent course and very exciting to go through the process of device design with my team.

Yes, depending on your interest. This class is very focused towards orthopedic injuries and medical devices. This class is one of the few classes for BME majors that help with after college careers and real-world experiences. It is a very hands-on class, so be prepared to spend some time in the class but a lot of it is ideas and thinking of the next steps towards creating your prototype.

I would recommend this course to a student that is self-motivated and genuinely interested in medical device design. Lectures are somewhat engaging, but the real value is in the availability of the instructors, TAs, and mentors for students who have questions and seek out help. Additionally, the process of working on the end-of-semester project will be more valuable to those students who put more thought and effort into it.
Yes, and you don't even necessarily have to be a BME or MechE to enjoy this course. It is very accessible to engineers and non-engineers.
yes

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: occasional in-person guest lectures
some parts in-person
We had some in-person lectures at the beginning of class and since this class was project based, we had many in person meetings.
We had some in person lecture, a lot of remote lecture, remote office hours, and in person group project meetings.
Live virtual lecture + some in-person lectures/fieldtrips
N/A
In person classes and field trips, in person work with peers. Virtual office hours.
Partly online lecture with occasional in-person lectures.
In person
a mix of small in-person lecture with live virtual lectures
Also included a few live in-person lectures at the beginning of the semester, as well as optional virtual discussion sections/ office hours.
A mix of in-person and live virtual lectures, with both in person and virtual field trips.
Mixture of live virtual lectures and in person lectures as well as in person field trips
We also had a few field trips and some in person classes.
